head.title: Findings Challenge Guidelines For Weight Gain in Pregnancy

hedline.hl1: Findings Challenge Guidelines For Weight Gain in Pregnancy

block.p: Women whose weight gain during pregnancy meets the current recommendations are significantly more likely to have a 3-year-old who is overweight than those who gain less than the recommended amount, researchers report.

Guidelines from the Institute of Medicine say that a woman with a normal body-mass index of 19.8 to 26 should gain 25 to 35 pounds. Women with a lower than normal B.M.I. should gain slightly more, and those with a B.M.I. greater than 26 should gain 13 to 25 pounds.

Women whose weight gain during pregnancy meets the current recommendations are significantly more likely to have a 3-year-old who is overweight than those who gain less than the recommended amount, researchers report.

Guidelines from the Institute of Medicine say that a woman with a normal body-mass index of 19.8 to 26 should gain 25 to 35 pounds. Women with a lower than normal B.M.I. should gain slightly more, and those with a B.M.I. greater than 26 should gain 13 to 25 pounds.

Researchers studied 1,044 mother-child pairs. After controlling for prepregnancy B.M.I. and other factors, they found that women whose weight gain was in the recommended range were almost four times more likely to have a preschooler who was overweight as those who gained less. The 3-year-old children of mothers who gained more than recommended were also more likely to have higher systolic blood pressure. The study is in the April issue of The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.
A majority of mothers in the study gained more weight than is recommended, but gaining less than the recommended amount was not associated with any negative outcome.

''The guidelines should probably be re-evaluated,'' said Dr. Emily Oken, the lead author of the study. But, she added, ''It's a little too early to recommend gains less than the current guidelines indicate.''
